etymologies: late Middle English: from Old French, via Latin from Greek poros ‘passage, pore’

definitions: a minute opening in a surface, especially the skin or integument of an organism, through which gases, liquids, or microscopic particles can pass.
shortDefinitions: minute opening in surface through which gases, liquids, or microscopic particles may pass

etymologies: Middle English: perhaps related to peer

notes.text: People frequently confuse the verbs pore and pour. Pore is used with over or through and means ‘be absorbed in reading something’ (I spent hours poring over cookbooks), while pour means ‘flow or cause to flow in a steady stream’ (water poured off the stones; pour the marinade over the pork). As pore is a much less common word, people often choose the more familiar pour, producing sentences such as she was pouring over books and studying till midnight. Although increasingly common, this use is incorrect in standard English

definitions: be absorbed in the reading or study of

examples.text: Heather spent hours poring over cookbooks

shortDefinitions: be absorbed in reading or studying

examples.text: when he has thought and pored on it
